On Dec 21, 2009, at 4:19 PM, mike amundsen wrote:

> <snip>
> The allowable subset of methods on a given resource isn't strictly
> defined by the representation.  In HTTP, OPTIONS would be the way to
> determine that, right?
> </snip>

The most common way of stating which methods to use are

- method to use is expressed at runtime by means of a form (e.g. HTML  
forms, OpenSearch's parameters extension)
- method to use is defined by media type specification (e.g. AtomPub)

Discovery at runtime is IMHO not really that useful except maybe for  
generic clients that crawl a URI space and record resource  
capabilities. Usually, if a client does not understand the semantics  
of a link well enough to immediately know the method, then finding out  
about the method is not the primary problem (understanding the link  
would be the primary thing to do).

Finding out about support for PUT might make sence because that  
enables the client to directly infer authorability of the resource.  
OTH, an Expect: 100-continue header on the PUT request would make the  
previous check for PUT unnecessary.

Jan

> So, this can be a dev-time check for some, but then I would treat this
> as a "hint" rather than a guarantee since the server can change this
> at some time in the future.
